title: Figurine
data:
| ( [![Figurine.png](/images/3/3c/Figurine.png)](/wiki/File:Figurine.png) |                                    |
| ----------------------------------------------------------------------- | ---------------------------------- |
| Name                                                                    | figurine                           |
| Appearance                                                              | figurine                           |
| Base price                                                              | 80 [zm](/wiki/Zorkmid "Zorkmid")   |
| Weight                                                                  | [50](/wiki/Weight "Weight")        |
| Material                                                                | [mineral](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral") |
| Monster use                                                             | *Will not be used by monsters.*    |

A **figurine** is a type of [magical tool](/wiki/Magical_tool "Magical tool") that appears in *[NetHack](/wiki/NetHack "NetHack")*. Figurines are akin to miniature [statues](/wiki/Statue "Statue"), and can be used to bring the monster it depicts to life. They are made of [mineral](/wiki/Mineral "Mineral").

[ ]

## Contents

- [1 Generation](#Generation)

- [2 Description](#Description)
  - [2.1 Figurines and beatitude](#Figurines_and_beatitude)

- [3 Strategy](#Strategy)
  - [3.1 Conducts](#Conducts)

- [4 History](#History)

- [5 Messages](#Messages)

- [6 Variants](#Variants)

  - [6.1 SLASH'EM](#SLASH.27EM)
  - [6.2 EvilHack](#EvilHack)
  - [6.3 SlashTHEM](#SlashTHEM)

- [7 Encyclopedia entry](#Encyclopedia_entry)

- [8 References](#References)

## Generation

Figurines are generated as a random monster, based upon a combination of your level at the time of its creation and the dungeon level. Non-undead [humans](/wiki/Human_\(monster_attribute\) "Human (monster attribute)") and [unique monsters](/wiki/Unique_monster "Unique monster") cannot have figurines made of them, and [wishing](/wiki/Wishing "Wishing") for one will result in a random figurine being given instead.[\[1\]](#cite_note-1)[\[2\]](#cite_note-2) Figurines are generated 75% uncursed, 12.5% blessed, and 12.5% cursed.[\[3\]](#cite_note-3)

Monsters brought to life from figurines will not have their [starting inventory](/wiki/Monster_starting_inventory "Monster starting inventory"). Creating a monster by bringing a figurine to life respects [genocide](/wiki/Genocide "Genocide"), but does not respect [extinction](/wiki/Extinction "Extinction") except for monsters with special limits such as [erinyes](/wiki/Erinyes "Erinyes") and [Nazgul](/wiki/Nazgul "Nazgul").[\[4\]](#cite_note-extinct-4)

## Description

You can bring a figurine to life by [applying](/wiki/Apply "Apply") it or using the [stone to flesh](/wiki/Stone_to_flesh "Stone to flesh") spell. Applying a figurine will prompt the player for a direction and generate it on the square closest to them in that direction, while the latter method will cause it to animate on its current square (or next to the player if in their inventory). If a figurine is applied to a square with a monster on it, the figurine will be lost and nothing will generate. Applying a figurine [>](/wiki/Angle_bracket "Angle bracket") or [<](/wiki/Angle_bracket "Angle bracket") will generate the monster on the closest open square even if you are surrounded by monsters, unless the entire level is filled. Attempting to apply a figurine onto solid rock or a square containing a [boulder](/wiki/Boulder "Boulder") will fail without using up the figure, but will generate the monster as normal if it has [phasing](/wiki/Phasing "Phasing").

If you [name](/wiki/Name "Name") a figurine and then successfully activate it, the monster created will have that name.

### Figurines and beatitude

A monster created from a figurine is most likely to be tame if the figurine was blessed, peaceful if it was uncursed, and hostile if it was cursed; however, even a blessed figurine may create a hostile monster, or a cursed figurine a tame monster. The odds are as follows:

|          | tame | peaceful | hostile |
| -------- | ---- | -------- | ------- |
| blessed  | 80%  | 10%      | 10%     |
| uncursed | 10%  | 80%      | 10%     |
| cursed   | 10%  | 10%      | 80%     |

A cursed figurine will automatically transform anywhere between 200 to 9200 turns after it is cursed or placed into an inventory[\[5\]](#cite_note-5) - this timer starts whenever a cursed figurine is picked up or an existing figurine is cursed; dropping or uncursing the figurine will stop the timer.[\[6\]](#cite_note-6)[\[7\]](#cite_note-7)[\[8\]](#cite_note-8) A figurine that transforms is treated as if you applied the figurine yourself, e.g. there is a 4⁄5 chance the monster will be hostile; if this transformation would fail for any reason, the timer is set again for anywhere between one and 5000 turns.[\[9\]](#cite_note-9)

## Strategy

- *See also: [Preferred pets](/wiki/Pet#Preferred_pets "Pet")*

A blessed figurine of a powerful rare pet can prove to be a tempting [wish](/wiki/Wish "Wish") for some players - some players will wish for a blessed figurine of an [Archon](/wiki/Archon "Archon") for general power, or a [ki-rin](/wiki/Ki-rin "Ki-rin") for a powerful [riding](/wiki/Riding "Riding") steed. The link above provides more detail on which pets you may want for such a wish - remember that there is a 1⁄10 chance that the monster will be hostile, which may spell doom for you if the figurine backfires and you are not prepared to deal with the created monster. It may be a good idea to stand close to a [staircase](/wiki/Staircase "Staircase") when applying it, e.g. so you can #[jump](/wiki/Jump "Jump") to escape a potential death.

Also of note is the 1⁄10 chance that a blessed figurine will generate a peaceful monster: this at least means you can attempt to use [charm monster](/wiki/Spellbook_of_charm_monster "Spellbook of charm monster") or a [scroll of taming](/wiki/Scroll_of_taming "Scroll of taming") on it whenever either option becomes available, though monsters like Archons or ki-rins are very likely to resist multiple attempts due to their [high monster MR](/wiki/Magic_resistance_\(monster\) "Magic resistance (monster)").

Non-blessed figurines can be used to generate a peaceful or hostile creature in the path of more dangerous foes; while tame monsters can be used for similar purposes, they may attempt to attack if they are at a high enough level, and depending on their power level they may risk being killed. Figurines have an additional, more mundane use as a means of generating corpses for sacrifice, and unwanted figurines also make ideal [polypile](/wiki/Polypile "Polypile") fodder.

### Conducts

For [pacifist](/wiki/Pacifist "Pacifist") [conduct](/wiki/Conduct "Conduct") play, a blessed figurine of an Archon is often an early wish; for [illiterate](/wiki/Illiterate "Illiterate") conduct, figurines provide a means of generating particular monsters without relying on a scroll or spellbook.

Some players that are about to [ascend](/wiki/Ascend "Ascend") a character on their high altar will opt to wish up a particular figuring, e.g. a blessed [greased](/wiki/Greased "Greased") figurine of a [foocubus](/wiki/Foocubus "Foocubus"), in preparation for the "[demigod bar](/wiki/Demigod_bar "Demigod bar")".

## History

The figurine first appears in [NetHack 3.0.0](/wiki/NetHack_3.0.0 "NetHack 3.0.0"). From this version to [NetHack 3.4.3](/wiki/NetHack_3.4.3 "NetHack 3.4.3"), including variants based on those versions, applying a figurine generated the monster with its starting inventory.[\[10\]](#cite_note-10) Archons are even more popular pets in these versions, since applying a figurine of one would generate it with [Demonbane](/wiki/Demonbane "Demonbane") or [Sunsword](/wiki/Sunsword "Sunsword") and a [shield of reflection](/wiki/Shield_of_reflection "Shield of reflection"); a [bullwhip](/wiki/Bullwhip "Bullwhip") can then be used to disarm the Archon and take the [artifact weapon](/wiki/Artifact_weapon "Artifact weapon") for yourself if you wish.

## Messages

- You set the figurine beside you and it transforms.

  You applied a figurine.

- You set the figurine beside you and it transforms.  
  ...into a pile of dust.

  You applied a figurine of a [Nazgul](/wiki/Nazgul "Nazgul") or [erinys](/wiki/Erinys "Erinys") after they were extinct.[\[4\]](#cite_note-extinct-4)

- You get a bad feeling about this.

  The monster from an applied figurine was generated hostile.[\[11\]](#cite_note-11)

- The figurine writhes and then shatters into pieces!

  You applied a figurine to an occupied square, or the applied figurine was of a genocided monster. This destroys the figurine.[\[12\]](#cite_note-12)

- You see \<monster> drop out of your pack!

  You were carrying a cursed figurine, which spontaneously transformed.

- You suddenly see a figurine transform into \<monster>.

  A cursed figurine on the ground suddenly transformed.

## Variants

### SLASH'EM

In [SLASH'EM](/wiki/SLASH%27EM "SLASH'EM"), [pet shops](/wiki/Pet_shop "Pet shop") are a new type of [shop](/wiki/Shop "Shop") that often sells figurines of various monsters.

The [Planetar and Solar](/wiki/Planetar_and_Solar "Planetar and Solar") outrank the Archon as the popular pet of choice for figurine wishes in SLASH'EM and its variants, due to being much more powerful as pets - Planetars and Solars are the only pets capable of reliably taking out [One-eyed Sam](/wiki/Black_market_\(SLASH%27EM\)#One-eyed_Sam "Black market (SLASH'EM)"), making a wish for a Solar/Planetar figurine commonplace when robbing the black market, though the pet cannot be led out of the [dungeon branch](/wiki/Dungeon_branch "Dungeon branch") afterward in such instances.

### EvilHack

In [EvilHack](/wiki/EvilHack "EvilHack"), monsters that obtain a wish may try to obtain a figurine of a powerful monster such as a [balrog](/wiki/Balrog "Balrog") in order to use it against you.

[The Idol of Moloch](/wiki/The_Idol_of_Moloch "The Idol of Moloch") is an [artifact](/wiki/Artifact "Artifact") figurine of a [horned devil](/wiki/Horned_devil "Horned devil") and the [Infidel](/wiki/Infidel "Infidel") [quest artifact](/wiki/Quest_artifact "Quest artifact"). It can be applied like a normal figurine to summon a random major demon, including a horned devil, without using up the artifact; invoking it on a cross-aligned altar will immediately convert it into one to [Moloch](/wiki/Moloch "Moloch"). Carrying the Idol also grants [magic resistance](/wiki/Magic_resistance "Magic resistance") and [half spell damage](/wiki/Half_spell_damage "Half spell damage"), along with improved [energy](/wiki/Energy "Energy") regeneration for Infidels in good standing with Moloch.

### SlashTHEM

In addition to SLASH'EM details, the [Corsair](/wiki/Corsair "Corsair") role in [SlashTHEM](/wiki/SlashTHEM "SlashTHEM") starts the game with a random figurine.

## Encyclopedia entry

Then it appeared in Paris at just about the time that Paris  
was full of Carlists who had to get out of Spain. One of  
them must have brought it with him, but, whoever he was, it's  
likely he knew nothing about its real value. It had been --  
no doubt as a precaution during the Carlist trouble in Spain  
\-- painted or enameled over to look like nothing more than a  
fairly interesting black statuette. And in that disguise,  
sir, it was, you might say, kicked around Paris for seventy  
years by private owners and dealers too stupid to see what  
it was under the skin.

\[ The Maltese Falcon, by Dashiell Hammett ]

## References

1. [↑](#cite_ref-1) [src/mkobj.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 952](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkobj.c#L952)
2. [↑](#cite_ref-2) [src/objnam.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 3955](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/objnam.c#L3955)
3. [↑](#cite_ref-3) [src/mkobj.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 953](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkobj.c#L953)
4. ↑ [4.0](#cite_ref-extinct_4-0) [4.1](#cite_ref-extinct_4-1) [src/dog.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 87](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/dog.c#L87)
5. [↑](#cite_ref-5) [src/timeout.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 990](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/timeout.c#L990)
6. [↑](#cite_ref-6) [src/mkobj.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1285](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkobj.c#L1285)
7. [↑](#cite_ref-7) [src/mkobj.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1362](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/mkobj.c#L1362)
8. [↑](#cite_ref-8) [src/invent.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1145](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/invent.c#L1145)
9. [↑](#cite_ref-9) [src/apply.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2118](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/apply.c#L2118)
10. [↑](#cite_ref-10) [dog.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 103](/wiki/Source:NetHack_3.4.3/dog.c#line103 "Source:NetHack 3.4.3/dog.c")
11. [↑](#cite_ref-11) [src/dog.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 102](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/dog.c#L102)
12. [↑](#cite_ref-12) [src/dog.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 107](https://github.com/NetHack/NetHack/blob/NetHack-3.6.7_Released/src/dog.c#L107)

[![This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.](/images/f/f7/Nh367-icon.png)](/wiki/NetHackWiki:Next_version "This article has been updated to reflect NetHack 3.6.7. Click here for more information.")
html:
Figurine

From NetHackWiki
Jump to navigation Jump to search
(
Name figurine
Appearance figurine
Base price 80 zm
Weight 50
Material mineral
Monster use Will not be used by monsters.

A figurine is a type of magical tool that appears in NetHack. Figurines are akin to miniature statues, and can be used to bring the monster it depicts to life. They are made of mineral.

Contents

  • 1 Generation
  • 2 Description
    • 2.1 Figurines and beatitude
  • 3 Strategy
    • 3.1 Conducts
  • 4 History
  • 5 Messages
  • 6 Variants
    • 6.1 SLASH'EM
    • 6.2 EvilHack
    • 6.3 SlashTHEM
  • 7 Encyclopedia entry
  • 8 References

Generation

Figurines are generated as a random monster, based upon a combination of your level at the time of its creation and the dungeon level. Non-undead humans and unique monsters cannot have figurines made of them, and wishing for one will result in a random figurine being given instead.[1][2] Figurines are generated 75% uncursed, 12.5% blessed, and 12.5% cursed.[3]

Monsters brought to life from figurines will not have their starting inventory. Creating a monster by bringing a figurine to life respects genocide, but does not respect extinction except for monsters with special limits such as erinyes and Nazgul.[4]

Description

You can bring a figurine to life by applying it or using the stone to flesh spell. Applying a figurine will prompt the player for a direction and generate it on the square closest to them in that direction, while the latter method will cause it to animate on its current square (or next to the player if in their inventory). If a figurine is applied to a square with a monster on it, the figurine will be lost and nothing will generate. Applying a figurine > or < will generate the monster on the closest open square even if you are surrounded by monsters, unless the entire level is filled. Attempting to apply a figurine onto solid rock or a square containing a boulder will fail without using up the figure, but will generate the monster as normal if it has phasing.

If you name a figurine and then successfully activate it, the monster created will have that name.

Figurines and beatitude

A monster created from a figurine is most likely to be tame if the figurine was blessed, peaceful if it was uncursed, and hostile if it was cursed; however, even a blessed figurine may create a hostile monster, or a cursed figurine a tame monster. The odds are as follows:

tame peaceful hostile
blessed 80% 10% 10%
uncursed 10% 80% 10%
cursed 10% 10% 80%

A cursed figurine will automatically transform anywhere between 200 to 9200 turns after it is cursed or placed into an inventory[5] - this timer starts whenever a cursed figurine is picked up or an existing figurine is cursed; dropping or uncursing the figurine will stop the timer.[6][7][8] A figurine that transforms is treated as if you applied the figurine yourself, e.g. there is a 4⁄5 chance the monster will be hostile; if this transformation would fail for any reason, the timer is set again for anywhere between one and 5000 turns.[9]

Strategy

See also: Preferred pets

A blessed figurine of a powerful rare pet can prove to be a tempting wish for some players - some players will wish for a blessed figurine of an Archon for general power, or a ki-rin for a powerful riding steed. The link above provides more detail on which pets you may want for such a wish - remember that there is a 1⁄10 chance that the monster will be hostile, which may spell doom for you if the figurine backfires and you are not prepared to deal with the created monster. It may be a good idea to stand close to a staircase when applying it, e.g. so you can #jump to escape a potential death.

Also of note is the 1⁄10 chance that a blessed figurine will generate a peaceful monster: this at least means you can attempt to use charm monster or a scroll of taming on it whenever either option becomes available, though monsters like Archons or ki-rins are very likely to resist multiple attempts due to their high monster MR.

Non-blessed figurines can be used to generate a peaceful or hostile creature in the path of more dangerous foes; while tame monsters can be used for similar purposes, they may attempt to attack if they are at a high enough level, and depending on their power level they may risk being killed. Figurines have an additional, more mundane use as a means of generating corpses for sacrifice, and unwanted figurines also make ideal polypile fodder.

Conducts

For pacifist conduct play, a blessed figurine of an Archon is often an early wish; for illiterate conduct, figurines provide a means of generating particular monsters without relying on a scroll or spellbook.

Some players that are about to ascend a character on their high altar will opt to wish up a particular figuring, e.g. a blessed greased figurine of a foocubus, in preparation for the "demigod bar".

History

The figurine first appears in NetHack 3.0.0. From this version to NetHack 3.4.3, including variants based on those versions, applying a figurine generated the monster with its starting inventory.[10] Archons are even more popular pets in these versions, since applying a figurine of one would generate it with Demonbane or Sunsword and a shield of reflection; a bullwhip can then be used to disarm the Archon and take the artifact weapon for yourself if you wish.

Messages

You set the figurine beside you and it transforms.
You applied a figurine.
You set the figurine beside you and it transforms.
...into a pile of dust.
You applied a figurine of a Nazgul or erinys after they were extinct.[4]
You get a bad feeling about this.
The monster from an applied figurine was generated hostile.[11]
The figurine writhes and then shatters into pieces!
You applied a figurine to an occupied square, or the applied figurine was of a genocided monster. This destroys the figurine.[12]
You see <monster> drop out of your pack!
You were carrying a cursed figurine, which spontaneously transformed.
You suddenly see a figurine transform into <monster>.
A cursed figurine on the ground suddenly transformed.

Variants

SLASH'EM

In SLASH'EM, pet shops are a new type of shop that often sells figurines of various monsters.

The Planetar and Solar outrank the Archon as the popular pet of choice for figurine wishes in SLASH'EM and its variants, due to being much more powerful as pets - Planetars and Solars are the only pets capable of reliably taking out One-eyed Sam, making a wish for a Solar/Planetar figurine commonplace when robbing the black market, though the pet cannot be led out of the dungeon branch afterward in such instances.

EvilHack

In EvilHack, monsters that obtain a wish may try to obtain a figurine of a powerful monster such as a balrog in order to use it against you.

The Idol of Moloch is an artifact figurine of a horned devil and the Infidel quest artifact. It can be applied like a normal figurine to summon a random major demon, including a horned devil, without using up the artifact; invoking it on a cross-aligned altar will immediately convert it into one to Moloch. Carrying the Idol also grants magic resistance and half spell damage, along with improved energy regeneration for Infidels in good standing with Moloch.

SlashTHEM

In addition to SLASH'EM details, the Corsair role in SlashTHEM starts the game with a random figurine.

Encyclopedia entry

Then it appeared in Paris at just about the time that Paris
was full of Carlists who had to get out of Spain. One of
them must have brought it with him, but, whoever he was, it's
likely he knew nothing about its real value. It had been --
no doubt as a precaution during the Carlist trouble in Spain
-- painted or enameled over to look like nothing more than a
fairly interesting black statuette. And in that disguise,
sir, it was, you might say, kicked around Paris for seventy
years by private owners and dealers too stupid to see what
it was under the skin.

[ The Maltese Falcon, by Dashiell Hammett ]

References

  2. ↑ src/objnam.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 3955
  3. ↑ src/mkobj.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 953
  4. ↑ 4.0 4.1 src/dog.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 87
  5. ↑ src/timeout.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 990
  6. ↑ src/mkobj.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1285
  7. ↑ src/mkobj.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1362
  8. ↑ src/invent.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 1145
  9. ↑ src/apply.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 2118
  10. ↑ dog.c in NetHack 3.4.3, line 103
  11. ↑ src/dog.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 102
  12. ↑ src/dog.c in NetHack 3.6.7, line 107

If you [[name]] a figurine and then successfully activate it, the monster created will have that name. ===Figurines and beatitude=== A monster created from a figurine is most likely to be tame if the figurine was blessed, peaceful if it was uncursed, and hostile if it was cursed; however, even a blessed figurine may create a hostile monster, or a cursed figurine a tame monster. The odds are as follows: {|class="prettytable" ! !! tame !! peaceful !! hostile |- !blessed | 80% || 10% || 10% |- !uncursed | 10% || 80% || 10% |- !cursed | 10% || 10% || 80% |} A cursed figurine will automatically transform anywhere between 200 to 9200 turns after it is cursed or placed into an inventory{{refsrc|src/timeout.c|990|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} - this timer starts whenever a cursed figurine is picked up or an existing figurine is cursed; dropping or uncursing the figurine will stop the timer.{{refsrc|src/mkobj.c|1285|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/mkobj.c|1362|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}{{refsrc|src/invent.c|1145|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} A figurine that transforms is treated as if you applied the figurine yourself, e.g. there is a {{frac|4|5}} chance the monster will be hostile; if this transformation would fail for any reason, the timer is set again for anywhere between one and 5000 turns.{{refsrc|src/apply.c|2118|version=NetHack 3.6.7}} ==Strategy== :''See also: [[Pet#Preferred pets|Preferred pets]]'' A blessed figurine of a powerful rare pet can prove to be a tempting [[wish]] for some players - some players will wish for a blessed figurine of an [[Archon]] for general power, or a [[ki-rin]] for a powerful [[riding]] steed. It may be a good idea to stand close to a [[staircase]] when applying it, e.g. so you can #[[jump]] to escape a potential death. Also of note is the {{frac|10}} chance that a blessed figurine will generate a peaceful monster: this at least means you can attempt to use {{spell of|charm monster}} or a [[scroll of taming]] on it whenever either option becomes available, though monsters like Archons or ki-rins are very likely to resist multiple attempts due to their [[Magic resistance (monster)|high monster MR]]. Non-blessed figurines can be used to generate a peaceful or hostile creature in the path of more dangerous foes; while tame monsters can be used for similar purposes, they may attempt to attack if they are at a high enough level, and depending on their power level they may risk being killed. Figurines have an additional, more mundane use as a means of generating corpses for sacrifice, and unwanted figurines also make ideal [[polypile]] fodder. ===Conducts=== For [[pacifist]] [[conduct]] play, a blessed figurine of an Archon is often an early wish; for [[illiterate]] conduct, figurines provide a means of generating particular monsters without relying on a scroll or spellbook. Some players that are about to [[ascend]] a character on their high altar will opt to wish up a particular figuring, e.g. a blessed [[greased]] figurine of a [[foocubus]], in preparation for the "[[demigod bar]]". ==History== The figurine first appears in [[NetHack 3.0.0]]. From this version to [[NetHack 3.4.3]], including variants based on those versions, applying a figurine generated the monster with its starting inventory.{{refsrc|dog.c|103}} Archons are even more popular pets in these versions, since applying a figurine of one would generate it with [[Demonbane]] or [[Sunsword]] and a [[shield of reflection]]; a [[bullwhip]] can then be used to disarm the Archon and take the [[artifact weapon]] for yourself if you wish. ==Messages== {{message|You set the figurine beside you and it transforms.|You applied a figurine.}} {{message|You set the figurine beside you and it transforms.
...into a pile of dust.|You applied a figurine of a [[Nazgul]] or [[erinys]] after they were extinct.}} {{message|You get a bad feeling about this.|The monster from an applied figurine was generated hostile.{{refsrc|src/dog.c|102|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}}} {{message|The figurine writhes and then shatters into pieces!|You applied a figurine to an occupied square, or the applied figurine was of a genocided monster. This destroys the figurine.{{refsrc|src/dog.c|107|version=NetHack 3.6.7}}}} {{message|You see drop out of your pack!|You were carrying a cursed figurine, which spontaneously transformed.}} {{message|You suddenly see a figurine transform into .|A cursed figurine on the ground suddenly transformed.}} ==Variants== ===SLASH'EM=== In [[SLASH'EM]], [[pet shop]]s are a new type of [[shop]] that often sells figurines of various monsters. The [[Planetar and Solar]] outrank the Archon as the popular pet of choice for figurine wishes in SLASH'EM and its variants, due to being much more powerful as pets - Planetars and Solars are the only pets capable of reliably taking out [[Black market (SLASH'EM)#One-eyed Sam|One-eyed Sam]], making a wish for a Solar/Planetar figurine commonplace when robbing the black market, though the pet cannot be led out of the [[dungeon branch]] afterward in such instances. ===EvilHack=== In [[EvilHack]], monsters that obtain a wish may try to obtain a figurine of a powerful monster such as a [[balrog]] in order to use it against you. [[The Idol of Moloch]] is an [[artifact]] figurine of a [[horned devil]] and the [[Infidel]] [[quest artifact]]. It can be applied like a normal figurine to summon a random major demon, including a horned devil, without using up the artifact; invoking it on a cross-aligned altar will immediately convert it into one to [[Moloch]]. Carrying the Idol also grants [[magic resistance]] and [[half spell damage]], along with improved [[energy]] regeneration for Infidels in good standing with Moloch. ===SlashTHEM=== In addition to SLASH'EM details, the [[Corsair]] role in [[SlashTHEM]] starts the game with a random figurine. ==Encyclopedia entry== {{encyclopedia| Then it appeared in Paris at just about the time that Paris was full of Carlists who had to get out of Spain. One of them must have brought it with him, but, whoever he was, it's likely he knew nothing about its real value. It had been -- no doubt as a precaution during the Carlist trouble in Spain -- painted or enameled over to look like nothing more than a fairly interesting black statuette. And in that disguise, sir, it was, you might say, kicked around Paris for seventy years by private owners and dealers too stupid to see what it was under the skin. |[ The Maltese Falcon, by Dashiell Hammett ] }} ==References== {{nethack-367}} [[Category:Tools]]
